recommendations: Pique Turn is a movement performed in the passé position while turning to the inside and  usually done in a series.. For practicing Pique Turn as a/an intermediate performance, the recommended warm-up exercises are Plie variations: Try doing grand plies in first, second, and fifth positions, as well as demi-plies with various arm positions. , Releves variations: Single-leg, double-legs in first, second and fifth positions, releve passé, Arabesque balances, Spotting exercises: Doing half-turns or full turns with a focus on spotting, Flexibility stretching for 3 repetitions on each side for 5 minutes. After warming up, you should practice the following instructions: Begin with your feet in first position, heels touching and toes pointing outward. Evenly distribute the weight between your feet and core muscles for balance and control., Prepare for the turn by lifting your back foot into a pique position, bringing it to the back of your supporting ankle. Hold this position firmly and securely, and make sure your weight is centered over your supporting foot., Use your supporting leg to initiate the turn by pushing off the ground and lifting your pique foot into a passe position in front of your knee. Keep your core muscles engaged and your arms in a comfortable position for balance and control., As you turn, pivot on your supporting leg and bring your pique foot around to the front, pointing your toes and keeping your leg straight. Keep your eyes focused on a fixed point in front of you to help with spotting, and use your core muscles to help you maintain your balance and control throughout the turn.            , Complete the turn by landing on your supporting leg with your pique foot still in front of your knee. for 3 repetitions on each side for 5 minutes. Since you want to particularly focus on coordination, additional exercises could include Pirouette with arms: Practice turning with different arm positions to improve your coordination. Start with simple arm positions and gradually increase the difficulty., Spotting practice: Improve your spotting technique by practicing half and full turns with a focus on spotting. Gradually increase the speed and difficulty of the turns., Quick footwork patterns: Improve your coordination and footwork by practicing quick combinations, such as chasses, sissonnes, and pas de bourrees..

Axel Turn is a jump in which the skater rotates 360 degrees in the air, landing on the back foot.. For practicing Axel Turn as a/an advanced performance, the recommended warm-up exercises are Depth jumps, Plyometric single-leg box jumps, Bounding exercises for 3 repetitions for 5 minutes. After warming up, you should practice the following instructions: Start in B-plus position., Swing arms forward, then up into crossed position., Jump off back foot, bringing legs into crossed position., Rotate 540 degrees or more, maintaining crossed leg position., Land on the back foot, bending knees to absorb impact. for 3 repetitions for 5 minutes. Since you want to particularly focus on coordination, additional exercises could include Pirouette with arms, Spotting practice, Quick footwork patterns.

Hitch Kick is a jump in which the skater kicks the back leg forward, then lands on the front foot.. For practicing Hitch Kick as a/an amateur performance, the recommended warm-up exercises are Leg swings, High knees, Basic hop for 3 repetitions for 5 minutes. After warming up, you should practice the following instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart., Kick leading leg forward., Hop on supporting leg., Kick trailing leg forward., Land on trailing leg, leading leg in front. for 3 repetitions for 5 minutes. Since you want to particularly focus on coordination, additional exercises could include Pirouette with arms, Spotting practice, Quick footwork patterns.
